I guess what you mean is you’ve memorised a lot of vocabularies. Then after a few days, due to the lack of usage and revision, you’ve totally forgotten what you have supposedly learnt before. I’ve been there, done that. My personal advice for you is to try to “understand the words better”, to dig deeper for several possible meanings and find some ways to use these words in your daily conversations. Meanwhile, it would be great if you could master a few simple sentence structures and start organising your newly learnt vocab into complete sentences. If you happen to be reading, no matter it’s an online journal, newspaper or just a random magazine, try to translate it word by word from English to Chinese. It would be a quick and effective way to Improve.

replies.msg:
Let’s say “have doing” in your sentence. There’s no such thing in English language..

It’s either “have done”, which indicates that your actions have ended and lasted for a period
Or “am doing”, which indicates that your action is still ongoing

And it’s just about the collocations, that it makes more sense to say with certain words, like “I was a security guard” instead of “I do security”, or “I read books” instead of “I watch the books”

Because there’s a subtle difference between read and watch, read is for words, watch is for motions. So we use read for books. And it’s better to not use “the books” because you aren’t talking about a certain group of books. So it’s better to leave the “the” if you’re saying reading generally

Ps, I’m not a professional English tutor tho, Im just a chef studied maths in uni. I just thought that it’s good for both of us by doing this

It’s either “have done”, which indicates that your actions have ended and lasted for a period
Or “am doing”, which indicates that your action is still ongoing

And it’s just about the collocations, that it makes more sense to say with certain words, like “I was a security guard” instead of “I do security”, or “I read books” instead of “I watch the books”

Because there’s a subtle difference between read and watch, read is for words, watch is for motions. So we use read for books. And it’s better to not use “the books” because you aren’t talking about a certain group of books. So it’s better to leave the “the” if you’re saying reading generally

Ps, I’m not a professional English tutor tho, Im just a chef studied maths in uni. I just thought that it’s good for both of us by doing this

Hmm, it's quite a confusing sentence and I seem to have confused myself a bit as well.

normally people express it this way:
"At one point I would have been doing a PhD had I not given up."

So it's a conditional sentence referring to a hypothetical scenario of a decision made in the past, that would have led to a continuing situation until now.

I think it's called "Conditional Perfect Progressive".

This form of verb “to + Infinitive”, you should never use “ing” form or anything else following “to”
In that case, you should say “try to wait”, and also the preposition should be “for” if it’s followed by the object you’re waiting

Note that sometimes “to” could be followed by “ing” form of verbs IF “to” is a preposition in the case. For instance:
I’m looking forward to meeting you
That’s a typical example of an “ing” form following a “to”

quote.msg:
This form of verb “to + Infinitive”, you should never use “ing” form or anything else following “to”
In that case, you should say “try to wait”, and also the preposition should be “for” if it’s followed by the object you’re waiting

Note that sometimes “to” could be followed by “ing” form of verbs IF “to” is a preposition in the case. For instance:
I’m looking forward to meeting you
That’s a typical example of an “ing” form following a “to”

So, For example:
I’m looking forward to joining for game.
Is it correct?

Do you know any other instance?

Thank you

It’s just some phrasal verbs toward another verb,
“Look forward to” is a phrasal verb, so the verb “meeting”
Let’s say “I’m used to” means that I’m familiar with something, like “I’m used to those arseholes being such a dick to me”
When you are using this phrasal verb toward another action, it should be also in “ing” form
eg, I’m used to getting up early

replies.msg:
Well not necessarily, e.g. "where are you living?"
I think it's more about having only one main verb.

Note that the difference between "where do you live" and "where are you living" is quite subtle.
The former feels more permanent, while the latter feels more temporary.
So if you know someone who's moving home a lot, the next time you meet him, you'd probably ask, "where are you living?"

Something like that. Correct me if I'm wrong.

hi may I know what is your purpose for learning English

replies.msg: I think learning English is the first step of widening your horizons. Your knowledge, your social networks, your career will be limited if you don’t know any English. Most of the studies in the world are written in English, with only a small part of them are translated to Chinese. You won’t be able to learn things if there’s no one translating studies. Not to mention those translations could be misinterpreted or even misleading. Although China has been getting greater and greater, it’s still the the whole picture of the world and surely many of Hong Kong people wouldn’t have any interest in reaching out in China. A high English proficiency allows you to take any opportunity around the world. You can even work in Shanghai by just speaking English if you want to. But pretty sure you can’t just speak Chinese in France or UK unless you work in China town. I think it’s really personal for someone who decides to learn English. Some people can be pretty alright living in their comfort zone, reading content farms’ articles, getting stuck on their career, living in a boring town until they die. But some people can’t.

Some people can be pretty alright living in their comfort zone, reading content farms’ articles, getting stuck on their career, living in a boring town until they die. But some people can’t.
